results.title: Loosening the screws
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Last governor”.
China turns on the heat, promising to tear up Patten’s blueprint. Increasing anxieties about Hong Kong’s freedoms after 1997 form a backdrop for the film’s coverage of the 1995 elections to the Legislative Council. They turn out to be a triumph for democracy and for Patten, but they are soon overshadowed by struggles over other major issues like the Bill of Rights, the Court of Final Appeal and a bitter conflict about British passports for Hong Kong citizens.

results.title: Heroes Unsung
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Last dream: a special report by John Pilger”.
Part One of a three part series which explores aspects of Australia’s history. In this part, John Pilger traces the history of Australian immigration, from a personal perspective, from the horrors of the First Fleet through to the “White Australia” policy and the post-war “Populate or Perish” program. He challenges Australia’s treasured stereotypes and self-image and instead shows the great hardships suffered by certain groups, namely convicts, immigrants, women and Aborigines, in the process of building the nation.

results.title: Secrets
results.creator_credit: Alan Lowery and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Last dream: a special report by John Pilger”.
Part two of John Pilger’s personal view of Australian history and identity. This part is about the past catching up with the present. Behind the Bicentennial ballyhoo, the original Australians are treated as badly as many blacks in South Africa; and, for an increasing number of whites, the old egalitarian ways no longer have a place in a media conscious “lucky country” which now produces fine wines, films and thousands of overnight millionaires whilst many of its children are living in poverty.

results.title: Other people's wars
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Last dream: a special report by John Pilger”.
The final episode of a three part series which explores aspects of Australia’s history. This part shows how Australians fight mostly against people with whom they have no quarrel and who offer them no threat of invasion. From the Boxer Rebellion in China to the Boer War in Africa, to the disaster in Vietnam, Australians have paid a unique blood sacrifice to appease a great protector.

results.brief_description: A three part series in which John Pilger explores aspects of Australia’s history from first settlement, through its involvement in wars right through to today’s society, and looks at the plight of the Aborigines throughout Australian history.

results.title: Some have magnetic properties
results.creator_credit: D. Keith Carlson and WGBH Educational Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Kindergarten child series”.
In this film a teacher gives egg cartons filled with magnets to the children, encouraging them to discover which have magnetic properties. Various children explore contacts with iron filings, a compass, paper clips, and numerous other objects. Freedom not to be involved is open to the children here, but they are on the whole, quite involved in the project.

results.title: Discussion
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Kindergarten child series”.
Intending to stimulate language development and curiosity, and enlargement of concepts, understanding, the teacher introduces some human vertebrae and discusses their relation to the human form, allowing the children to handle the bones. For preschool eduction.

results.title: A Child
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Kindergarten child series”.
Illustrates the importance of a teacher’s observation of individual behaviour in the classroom situation. An indecisive child is directed to pursue an activity through one-to-one contact with the teacher.

results.title: Free play and music
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Kindergarten child series”.
Children are encouraged to select toys or materials which interest them, each child directing his own activity with the objects. Music periods involve singing accompanied by physical participation.
